Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. The movie is divided into two parts: Early and Later, dedicated to the moments of the first half of his life, and the second half respectively. This film is a poetic illustration of a very well-known Japanese poet, instead of creating a conventional biopic.

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was originally a novel that was initially republished as a film script. The film won the Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 1974 but also was booed at certain screenings. "Les Valseuses" is funny, provocative. and provides a rare insight

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John Carroll, Eric Campbell, and George Wood with enough bad guys to necessitate the need for stuntmen, brilliant photography (Spanische Toledo being heavily intercut with 'authentic' Spain, and a great cast. The writing is quick-paced, and is almost always on the money

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The townspeople form a lynch mob to deal with the cat.
Amanda has just lived through the death of her beloved husband, and loves her new neighbors. But when a strange visitor comes knocking it is obvious that Amanda is the next in line of "fellowship." Snickerdoodle Pictures,
